Re ''How, but Not Why, the Brain Distinguishes Race,'' Sept. 5): What's the mystery about why our brain distinguishes race? The ability to tell whether an individual is ''like me'' or ''not like me'' is of such value that it is common all through the animal kingdom.
It tells us who is friend and who is enemy; whom to include when we ''circle the wagons,'' whom to keep out. Or, on the other hand, whom to accept as a mate, whom not.
Troops of monkeys defend their territories, lions their prides, ants their colonies. Humans depend on visual clues, bees and ants on odor, songbirds on the voices they hear.

The human propensity to classify extends beyond skin color. Don't we find ourselves reacting exactly as if meeting someone of a different race when we hear a foreign accent or see someone in exotic dress?
We even have artificial races -- religions, secret societies, fraternities, alumni groups -- all of which meet our need to (prejudicially) accept some individuals and reject others.
